newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - June 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - June 23.

text.p: Following are the highlights of Monday's Irish press.

THE IRISH INDEPENDENT - Irish police sources are still hopeful of an early IRA ceasefire despite the blows dealt to the peace process by the murder of two Northern Ireland police and Loyalist reprisals. - A notorious Dublin crime boss known as the Monk has been served with a tax bill for almost 400,000 irish pounds. - Thousands of Gaelic football fans were evacuated from the multi-million pound Cusack Stand of Crowke park after it became overcrowded during a championship match.

THE IRISH TIMES - British Prime Minister Tony Blair said Sinn Fein cannot hold the peace process to ransom by not joining it. - North Korean workers are reduced to eating seaweed and grass, according to an Irish aid team. - Russia's Justice Minister, Valentin Kovalyov, may soon have no job after being caught on video cavorting in a sauna with women.

THE EXAMINER - Sinn Fein negotiator Martin McGuinness has ruled out efforts to disarm the IRA until talks on Northern Irleand make progress. - Administrative problems have been blamed for overcrowding at Dublin's Crowke Park Gaelic football ground. - Chelsea Clinton, teenage daugher of the U.S. President, has arrived in Ireland for a short private holiday.
